questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with sinusitis, hematuria, and hemoptysis. c-ANCA is positive. What is the first-line induction therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide

• GPA (Wegener’s) = necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving respiratory tract + kidneys.
• c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positive.
• Treatment: induction with steroids + cyclophosphamide/rituximab, maintenance with azathioprine or methotrexate.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with malar rash, oral ulcers, and arthritis. Her ANA is positive, dsDNA is high, and urine shows protein 2+. What is the most likely renal lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis

• Diffuse proliferative GN (Class IV) is the most common and most severe renal lesion in SLE.
• Presents with proteinuria, hematuria, hypertension, renal dysfunction.
• dsDNA levels correlate with disease activity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with fatigue has Hb 8 g/dL, MCV 68 fL, ferritin 10 ng/mL. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Oral ferrous sulfate

• Low ferritin = iron deficiency anemia.
• Treat with oral iron (ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS) for 3 months after Hb normalization.
• Evaluate source of blood loss (menstrual/GI).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has petechiae, platelets 15,000/mm3, normal Hb and WBC. Peripheral smear showed large platelets. No splenomegaly. Next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

IV steroids

• ITP: isolated thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies.
• First-line: corticosteroids (prednisolone).
• IVIG if severe bleeding or need rapid rise in platelets.
• Splenectomy for chronic/refractory case

questions.text: A patient with septic shock develops bleeding from IV sites. Labs: PT prolonged, aPTT prolonged, low fibrinogen, high D-dimer. Best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Fresh frozen plasma

• DIC = consumption of coagulation factors + fibrinolysis.
• FFP replaces clotting factors; platelets if less than 50,000 with bleeding.
• Heparin may be used only in chronic, non-bleeding DIC.

choices.text: Onset of critical phase with plasma leakage

questions.text: A patient with dengue presents with abdominal pain and rising hematocrit but stable platelets. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Onset of critical phase with plasma leakage

• Rising hematocrit = hemoconcentration due to plasma leakage → critical phase.
• Warning signs: abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, lethargy, bleeding, hepatomegaly.
• Manage with careful isotonic fluid replacement.

questions.text: A 20-year-old presents with relative bradycardia and coated tongue. Blood culture grows Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Ceftriaxone

• Increasing fluoroquinolone resistance in Salmonella typhi → 3rd-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone/cefixime) are first-line.
• Azithromycin is an oral alternative for uncomplicated cases.

questions.text: A head injury patient has polyuria (8 L/day), Na⁺ 156 mmol/L, urine osmolality 100 mosm/Kg water. After desmopressin, urine osmolality rises to 400. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Central DI

• Central DI: ADH deficiency → low urine osmolality, responds to desmopressin.
• Nephrogenic DI: No response to desmopressin.
• SIADH: Low serum Na⁺, concentrated urine.

questions.text: A patient on thiazide diuretics has Na⁺ = 115 mEq/L with confusion and seizures. What is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

IV 3% saline bolus

• Severe symptomatic hyponatremia → treat with 3% hypertonic saline (100 mL bolus over 10 min).
• Goal: raise Na⁺ by 4–6 mEq/L in first 6 hrs.
• Avoid rapid correction → risk of osmotic demyelination

questions.text: A postoperative patient has oliguria (urine less than 400 mL/day). Urine Na⁺ = 10 mEq/L, urine osmolality = 600 mOsm/kg. What is the likely type of AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Prerenal

• Prerenal AKI: Low urine Na⁺ (less than 20), high urine osmolality (greater than 500), due to decreased perfusion (e.g. dehydration, shock).
• Intrinsic (ATN): Urine Na⁺ greater than 40, osmolality less than 350.

questions.text: A CKD patient has K⁺ = 7.2 mEq/L, ECG is normal. What is the most urgent step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Give calcium gluconate IV

• Immediate priority = stabilize cardiac membrane with 10 mL of 10 percent calcium gluconate IV over 5–10 min.
• Then shift K⁺ intracellularly with insulin + glucose, and remove K⁺ via resins/dialysis.

questions.text: A known Addison’s patient with vomiting and hypotension after gastroenteritis. Na⁺ 122 mmol/L, K⁺ 6.2 mmoml/L, glucose 60 mg/dl.What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

IV fluids + IV hydrocortisone

• Adrenal crisis: ↓cortisol → shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia.
• Treat immediately with IV normal saline + IV hydrocortisone (100 mg bolus, then 50 mg q6h).

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, and altered sensorium. Her TSH is high, T4 is very low. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IV levothyroxine and hydrocortisone

• Myxedema coma = severe hypothyroidism + altered mental state.
• Treat with IV thyroxine (T4) ± small dose T3, and IV hydrocortisone (for possible adrenal insufficiency).
• Supportive: warming, fluids, ventilatory support.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with BP 220/130 mmHg, headache, and papilledema. What is the preferred drug for BP control?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Labetalol

• Hypertensive emergency = BP > 180/120 + target organ damage.
• IV labetalol or nicardipine → gradual BP reduction (≤ 25% in 1 h).
• Oral agents contraindicated in acute setting

questions.text: A patient develops ascending weakness 4 weeks after a diarrheal illness. CSF shows high protein with normal cell count. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Start IV immunoglobulin

• GBS: Albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF.
• Treatment = IVIG (0.4 g/kg × 5 days) or plasmapheresis.
• Steroids are not effective.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male with fever, headache, and neck stiffness. CSF shows: protein 200 mg/dL, glucose 25 mg/dL (serum 90 mg/dL), neutrophils 90%. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Bacterial meningitis

• Bacterial: High protein, low glucose (< 40% serum), neutrophilic predominance.
• Viral: Normal glucose, lymphocytic.
• TB/fungal: Low glucose, lymphocytic, moderate protein rise.

questions.text: A 65-year-old ICU patient with fever has BP 80/50 mmHg, lactate 4 mmol/L despite 30 mL/kg fluid bolus. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Start norepinephrine infusion

• Septic shock = MAP < 65> 2 mmol/L after adequate fluids.
• First-line vasopressor → norepinephrine.
• Corticosteroids are added only if shock is refractory to fluids + vasopressors.

questions.text: A 22-year-old type 1 diabetic presents with Kussmaul breathing and abdominal pain. ABG shows pH 7.1, HCO₃⁻ 10 mmol/L, glucose 480 mg/dL. What is the most important initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

IV fluids with normal saline

• First step in DKA = restore volume with isotonic saline.
• Insulin started after initial fluid resuscitation.
• K⁺ is replaced after insulin starts if K⁺ less than 5.5 mmol/L
• Bicarbonate rarely indicated unless pH less than 6.9.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with long-standing hypertension presents with dyspnea, orthopnea, and bilateral basal crepitations. BNP is elevated. What is the first-line drug for symptom relief?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Loop diuretic

• For acute decompensated heart failure, loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide) relieve pulmonary congestion quickly.
• ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers are for long-term mortality benefit once the patient is stabilized.

choices.text: Large bore needle in 5 intercostal space

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with dyspnea, hypotension, raised JVP, and RV diastolic collapse after chest wall trauma. What is the most definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Emergency pericardiocentesis

• The triad (Beck’s triad) → hypotension + muffled heart sounds + raised JVP → Cardiac tamponade.
• Immediate pericardiocentesis is lifesaving by relieving pressure on the heart.

choices.text: Start dual antiplatelet and arrange for primary PCI
Start IV heparin and monitor for 24 hours
Give oxygen and wait for enzyme results

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with chest pain radiating to the left arm for 2 hours. ECG shows ST elevation in V1–V4. What is the most appropriate immediate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Start dual antiplatelet and arrange for primary PCI

• STEMI within 12 hours of symptom onset → Primary PCI is the preferred therapy if available within 90–120 min.
• Start aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor (e.g. ticagrelor) immediately.
• Thrombolysis is considered if PCI not available within time window

questions.text:
A 25-year-old healthcare worker’s screening report shows:

• HBsAg – Negative

• Anti-HBs – Positive

• Anti-HBc – Negative

What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Immunity due to vaccination

Presence of anti-HBs alone indicates immunity following vaccination.

Past natural infection would show both anti-HBs and anti-HBc positive.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with ascites. Ascitic fluid analysis shows:

• Total protein = 1.2 g/dL

• Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) = 1.5 g/dL

What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Cirrhosis-related portal hypertension

SAAG greater than 1.1 g/dL → portal-hypertensive cause (cirrhosis, Budd-Chiari, CHF).

SAAG less than 1.1 g/dL → non-portal causes (TB, malignancy, nephrotic).

choices.text: Normal ceruloplasmin, ↑ Serum copper, ↓ Urinary copper

questions.text: In Wilson disease, what is the expected pattern of biochemical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

↓ Ceruloplasmin, ↓ Serum copper, ↑ Urinary copper

Due to defective incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin, total serum copper falls, but free copper and urinary excretion rise.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with sudden palpitations. ECG is shown in figure. Vagal maneuvers and three doses of IV adenosine fail to terminate the arrhythmia. Blood pressure is stable. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Start IV verapamil

• Step 1: Vagal maneuvers (Valsalva, carotid massage).
• Step 2: IV adenosine (6 mg → 12 mg → 18 mg).
• Step 3: If PSVT persists and patient is hemodynamically stable, use rate-slowing calcium channel blockers (IV verapamil or diltiazem) or beta-blockers (metoprolol).
• Step 4: If unstable (hypotension, chest pain, syncope) → immediate synchronized DC cardioversion.
